title: Samuil Samosud
text:
Samuil Abramovich Samosud () (<a href="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>, — <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, 6 November 1964), <a href="People%27s%20Artist%20of%20the%20USSR">PAU</a>, was a <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> and <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n <a href="conducting">conductor</a>.
He started his musical career on the <a href="cello">cello</a>, before conducting in the <a href="Mariinsky%20Theater">Mariinsky Theater</a>, <a href="Petrograd">Petrograd</a> in 1917. From 1918 to 1936 he conducted at the <a href="Mikhailovsky%20Theatre">Maly Operny</a>, <a href="Saint%20Petersburg">Leningrad</a>. In 1936 he became musical director at the <a href="Bolshoi%20Theater">Bolshoi Theater</a>, <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>. He founded what became the <a href="Moscow%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra</a> in 1951. He premiered several important works, including <a href="Dmitri%20Shostakovich">Shostakovich</a>'s "<a href="Lady%20Macbeth%20of%20the%20Mtsensk%20District%20%28opera%29">Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District</a>", "<a href="The%20Nose%20%28opera%29">The Nose</a>", "<a href="Symphony%20No.%207%20%28Shostakovich%29">"Leningrad Symphony"</a>" and <a href="Sergei%20Prokofiev">Prokofiev</a>'s "<a href="War%20and%20Peace%20%28Prokofiev%29">War and Peace</a>". Shostakovich "had a high opinion" of Samosud's theatrical performances, and regarded him as "the supreme interpreter" of operatic works including "Lady Macbeth". Nonetheless, after Samosud premiered the "Leningrad Symphony", the composer wrote that he wanted to hear <a href="Mravinsky">Mravinsky</a> perform the symphony, as he didn't "have great faith in Samosud as a symphonic conductor".
